instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.820-2850: What is 820-2850? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U7201: What is U7201? U7201 is responsible for the 3.3v and 5v power rails on many devices..
definitions.TPS51125: What is TPS51125? This is a power chip responsible for the PP3V3_S5,  PP5V_S5,  and PP5V_S3 power rails on many A1278 model Macbooks.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V3_S5: What is PP3V3_S5? PP3V3_S5 is a 3.3v power rail when the system is in an S5 soft off power state.
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.SMC_ONOFF_L: What is SMC_ONOFF_L? SMC_ONOFF_L tells the computer that the power button has been pressed when it is low, _L means signal is asserted when it is low voltage. .
definitions.PP5V_S5: What is PP5V_S5? This is a 5v power rail that is present when the machine is in an S5 soft off state..
definitions.PM_PWRBTN_L: What is PM_PWRBTN_L? PM_PWRBTN_L refers to the power button signal line. This line is used to initiate the power-on sequence of the laptop. The "L" at the end of "PM_PWRBTN_L" suggests that it is an active-low signal, meaning that when the power button is pressed, the signal is pulled low to initiate the boot sequence..
definitions.SMC_RESET_L: What is SMC_RESET_L? SMC_RESET_L puts the SMC into reset mode when it is low, _L means the signal is present when voltage is low. The SMC being in reset mode keeps it from running..
definitions.PP5V_S3: What is PP5V_S3? PP5V_S3 is a 5v power rail present when the system is in an S3 suspend to RAM state..
definitions.5V_S3: What is 5V_S3? 5V_S3 is an abbreviation of “PP5V_S3” which is a 5 volt power rail present in an S3 state. S3 (Suspend to RAM) is a state where the system saves its context to RAM, a faster but more power-consuming method than S4. The system shuts down most components except for RAM, which remains powered to retain the system state. PM_SLP_S4_L is required for this rail to be present. .
definitions.PM_SLP_S4_L: What is PM_SLP_S4_L? PM_SLP_S4_L is a signal that puts the system into an S4 suspend to disk sleep state when it is low(_L means signal is asserted when voltage is low).
definitions.PM_BATLOW_L: What is PM_BATLOW_L? PM_BATLOW_L is a signal that tells the system the battery is too low for it to turn on & keeps it from turning on, when it is low. _L means the signal is asserted when its voltage is low. .
definitions.PLT_RST_L: What is PLT_RST_L? This is an abbreviation of “PLT_RESET_L” – when you see “PLT_RST_L", assume the person meant to type PLT_RESET_L.
definitions.PM_SYSRST_L: What is PM_SYSRST_L? PM_SYSRST_L is a system reset signal present when it is low, _L means the signal asserts itself when the voltage is low. This signal needs to be high for the system to exit reset mode & turn on properly. .
definitions.ISL6259: What is ISL6259? This is a charging chip for Macbook motherboards from 2010 through 2015.
definitions.R5280: What is R5280? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SDA which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.R5281: What is R5281? Pullup resistor between PP3V42_G3H and SMBUS_SMC_5_G3_SCL which is a data line that allows the SMC to communicate with the battery and the battery charging chip. This line is necessary for the battery to be recognized. With red probe on ground, diode mode should measure 0.441 on pin 2 of this resistor. .
definitions.SMC_BC_ACOK: What is SMC_BC_ACOK? This is identical to CHGR_ACOK. This will come out of the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging chip when CHGR_ACIN & CHGR_DCIN are present, and is necessary for the onewire circuit to begin working. On most Macbooks, CHGR_ACOK needs to be present in order for PP3V42_G3H to flow to the onewire circuit so that the circuitry that allows the charger to communicate with the SMC will turn on.  .
definitions.CHGR_ACIN: What is CHGR_ACIN? CHGR_ACIN is a signal that is created by a voltage divider between the charger and ground that goes into the ISL6258, ISL6259, ISL9239, or ISL9240 chip that creates PPBUS_G3H. It is necessary for SMC_BC_ACOK & CHGR_ACOK to be present so that the onewire circuit is told to turn on & allow the SMC to speak to the charger..
definitions.SMC_RESET: What is SMC_RESET? SMC_RESET is not a signal, it is an abbreviation for “SMC_RESET_L”, which is the signal someone is referring to when they type “SMC_RESET”  "SMC_RESET_L is a signal that resets the SMC when it is low(this is what the “_L” prefix means), and lets the SMC out of reset mode when it is high. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.CHGR_DCIN: What is CHGR_DCIN? CHGR_DCIN comes directly from charger into ISL6258 or ISL6259, the resistor before it can be blown when there are surges. Should be checked when PPBUS_G3H is missing.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I have an <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> board. The customer told me there was a liquid spill a long time but they cleaned it up and it was working for a long time until it stopped turning on one day.
When I plug in the charger I get a green light but no fan spin or anything. I removed the board from the machine in order to test the power rails.

<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> - 12.59v
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> - 3.4v

The current sensing pins on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> all measured properly.

<SIGNAL>PP5V_S5</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> are both present
<SIGNAL>PP5V_S3</SIGNAL>, <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S3</SIGNAL> and the S0 rails are missing

I checked <CHIP>U7201</CHIP> and these are some of the voltages I got.
Pin 1(ENTRIP1) - 0v
Pin 6(ENTRIP2) - 0v
Pin 4(TONSEL) - 4.96v

Is this an issue with the <CHIP>TPS51125</CHIP>?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: <SIGNAL>PP3V3_S5</SIGNAL> cannot be present if ENTRIP2 is low......should be 0.75V or so.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Yes. you are correct. ENTRIP2 is 0.875v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: First inspect board for corrosion closely. Check if <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> comes on for a fraction when plugging in the power.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I can't find any corrosion on the board since the customer said they cleaned the board after the liquid spill a while ago. I can see some probe points and pads on J2650 that look like they had liquid spilled on them.
I measured <SIGNAL>5V_S3</SIGNAL> and it is not coming on at all when the charger is plugged in.

I checked for <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> on <RESISTOR>R7912</RESISTOR> and I got 0v.

Should I throw this is in the ultrasonic and see if that fixes it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Well, yeah give it a clean first. You need to check <SIGNAL>SLP_S4</SIGNAL> when you plug it in, it may only pulse once.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Okay I gave the board an ultrasonic cleaning and still no change.
With my multimeter <SIGNAL>PM_SLP_S4_L</SIGNAL> is not present at all even when the charger is initially plugged in.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Check voltage <RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR>-03 on both sides.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Okay here are the measurements I took.
<RESISTOR>R1800</RESISTOR> - Pin 1(3.41v) Pin 2(3.31v)
<RESISTOR>R1801</RESISTOR> - Pin 1(3.41v) Pin 2(3.13v)
<RESISTOR>R1802</RESISTOR> - Pin 1(3.41v) Pin 2 (3.40v)
<RESISTOR>R1803</RESISTOR> - Pin 1(3.415v) Pin 2(3.409v)

I checked <SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SYSRST_L</SIGNAL> and I got 0v. <SIGNAL>PM_PWRBTN_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PM_SUS_PWR_ACK</SIGNAL> both show 3.4v
<SIGNAL>PLT_RST_L</SIGNAL> gives me around 0.25v as soon as I plug the charger in then it goes to and stays at 0v.

<SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> pulsed up to around 1.5v when the charger is first plugged in then it also goes down to 0v.

All of these measurements are done with only the board and no external components plugged in besides the dc-inboard and fans.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Uhm are you using a REAL 85W charger??

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Oh crap. I've been using a 60w charger this whole time. I will go to best buy and purchase an 85w charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Okay. I went and got a genuine 85w apple charger and it is still not turning on.
I re-took the measurements and they are the same except that <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> is now pulsing almost every 5 seconds and goes up to around 3v then back to 0v and it repeats.
<SIGNAL>PM_PCH_PWRGD</SIGNAL> is also pulsing every 5 seconds and goes up to around 0.31v.

Update: Now when I check <SIGNAL>PM_BATLOW_L</SIGNAL> it pulses up to around 0.85v as soon as the charger is plugged in and doesn't come back high.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Connect a battery and let it charge for a bit then check again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I connected the battery then the charger but the charger light is staying green and not turning orange. Shouldn't it turn orange once the battery is detected and charging?

Anyways I left it on the charger with the battery connected so I will check on it in a bit. What should I do afterwards. Short the <SIGNAL>SMC_ONOFF_L</SIGNAL> to ground and see if it turns on?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: It should turn orange. Does the battery indicator do anything when pressed?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: No nothing happens.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Well, that indicates a communication issue with the SMC. Check the data bus from SMC to battery on diode mode. But in your first measurements you say PPBUS @12.56V so SMC must be working. Disconnect battery indicator and try charging again.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I checked <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> in diode mode with no charger plugged in and this is what I got. The readings were the same for both resistors
Pin 1 - -OL
Pin 2 - -0.97v (Its showing what looks to be a negative number. Didnt know that was possible and the multimeter beeps the entire time I have the probe on pin 2)

In resistance mode both showed over 2kohms when the schematic says it should be 1kohms

The area around the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> looks clean with no liquid damage.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Measurements do not make sense. No idea what you are doing here....Red probe to GND black to the data bus, multimeter on diode mode. No power and battery of course!

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
When you say the data bus  are you referring to the 2 resistors <RESISTOR>R5280</RESISTOR> and <RESISTOR>R5281</RESISTOR> correct?

I had the battery plugged in which was probably causing those bad readings. I removed the battery and measured in diode mode with red probe on ground.
Pin 1 - 0.38v
Pin 2 - 0.503v 
The measurements were the same for both resistors.

Also, In resistance mode they are both measuring 2kohms.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
.503 seems ok.
Measure PPBUS again and see if it is at 12.3 or 12.56V

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Okay with only charger plugged in <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> pulses and is not stable from anywhere around 3v- 12v
With the battery plugged in and charger plugged in it pulses from around 12.1v to 12.5v
With the battery only it is at a stable 12.1v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I suspect a short, check all coils for shorts. You can remove F7040/41 and see if PPBUS is stable then.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
When you say check all coils for shorts which coils are you referring to?

The fuse 0v in diode mode so I believe it is fine. L7030 did not measure as a short.

I removed F7040 and checked <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> again and this is what I got.
Pin 1 - still pulses from 12.57 not stable.
Pin 2(<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>) - 0.56v and slowly goes down.

(Measurements with F7040 removed from the board)
I went and checked the current sensing on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> they all measured fine. I got 5v on VDD but on Pin 3(ACIN) I was getting 0v.
<DIODE>D7005</DIODE> is pulsing between 16.3v - 16.83v. Pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> also had the 16v but Pin 2 shows 0v.
In resistance mode <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> measured 30kohms but <RESISTOR>R7011</RESISTOR> measured only 2ohms.


While taking those measurements I noticed the charger light is now dim green and doesn't turn bright green anymore when I plug the charger. Tested with another Dcin board and same issue.
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> is 3.41 while <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 0v.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I don't know what you are doing but now it seems you killed the 6259.....
Also according to the diagram there are 2 fuses 7040 and 7041, no idea if they are on the board too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
There is no f7041 on the board.
I put F7040 back on the board and replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and the green light came back on and <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 3.1v and <SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL> is back at 3.9v
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is still at only giving me around 1.08v

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Well, remove F7040 and check again. This time don't kill the 6259...
If it still is not stable at 12.xx volts then check the sense resistors and traces.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Some more crap happened. I removed F7040 and measured Pin 1 of F7040 and it was stable around 6v. Pin 2 had around 0.3v. I unplugged the charger and plugged in back in about 10 seconds later and now I have no light on the charger at all. I didn't take any measurements other than on the pads of F7040 so I don't think I killed anything.
F6905 is pulsing and only goes up to 0.23v.

I measured the current sensing on <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>. Pins 27/28 - 20.5ohms Pins 17/18 - 3.1ohms
The traces are good when I measured in continuity mode.

I've tried putting F7040 back on but still no change and I tested with another Dc-in board and the same thing happens.

Is this issue worth continuing to troubleshoot it?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Did the charger trip? Test on other macbook or unplug for a few minutes.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I don't think its the charger. I plugged the charger into my 2011 MBA and the light came on the charger and it was working.
Its not the Dc-in board because I plugged the same one into a 2012 MBP and it had a light on the charger.

When I plug it back into the <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> there is no light on the charger at all.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Well, go check the usual for green light. 3V42? <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET</SIGNAL>? ACOK?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I get 0v on all of those. The only voltage I get is on <SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL>. It pulses every few seconds and only goes up to 0.25v

When I measure in diode mode on pin 1 of <RESISTOR>R7010</RESISTOR> I just get OL.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Something wrong in 6259 circuit. Do you have a fake chinese charger to check, it will not shut down like an Apple one.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I only have a fake 60w charger.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: 60W is fine for testing this.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
Ok. The fake charger lights up. <SIGNAL>SMC_RESET_L</SIGNAL> and <SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> are both high. <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL> is 3.26v and <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> is around 0.09v (F7040 is still removed from the board)
Pins 27/28 of <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> - 20.7ohms - Pins 17/18 - 3.1ohms

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Short on PPBUS?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
No short on <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>. In diode mode I get 0.49 on Pin 1 of F7040(<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL>).
Could this be an issue with the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>? Should I try putting a new ISL on there?

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Test all sense resistors and traces first then replace 6259

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message:
I think I might just send this machine back.
I replaced the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP> and the green light came on I was able to see <SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> was pulsing from 12.56 to 4v on Pin 1 of F7040. I also took some other measurements.
<CHIP>U7000</CHIP>
Pin 13(<SIGNAL>CHGR_RST_L</SIGNAL>) - 3.36v
Pin 3(<SIGNAL>CHGR_ACIN</SIGNAL>) - 4v
Pin 2(<SIGNAL>CHGR_DCIN</SIGNAL>) - Pulses from 16.2v to 15.7v

Then minutes later the green light went away as if the isl died again. I replaced with another 6259 and that had a dim green light until about 20 minutes later I plugged the charger in and the light turned green again. The light went away and I replaced the 6259 again and now it is again giving me a dim green light and 0v on <SIGNAL>SMC_BC_ACOK</SIGNAL>.
I don't know what keeps killing the <CHIP>ISL6259</CHIP>. All of the sense resistors and the traces are fine.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: I dunno, this may not be worth the effort. Could be SMC issue too.

threads.title: <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-2850</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER> not turning on
threads.message: Okay. This is going back.
